questions.text: Choose the correct response indicated by the arrow in the image below.
questions.solution:
1. Fish-tailing:
    • Occurs with a single-edged weapon causing a triangular or wedge-shaped wound.
    • One end of the wound is sharp, the other is blunt or rounded.
    • The blunt end shows small splits in the skin, resembling a fish tail.
    • Caused due to the tearing effect when the weapon is withdrawn.
  2. Significance:
    • Fish-tailing indicates the use of a single-edged stabbing weapon.
    • Helps in identifying the type of weapon used during forensic examination.

(Why Not Others):

  • B. Tailing:
    • Caused by knife withdrawal, resulting in a superficial scratch rather than a deep, triangular wound. Not seen here.
  • C. Hilt guard abrasion:
    • Happens when the weapon fully penetrates, and the hilt guard strikes the skin, creating a patterned abrasion or bruise, which is absent here.
  • D. Bevelling:
    • Appears when the weapon enters at an angle, causing bevelled margins on one side and undermining on the other. The image shows blunt-end splitting, not bevelling.

Key Takeaway:

Fish-tailing is a distinctive feature of wounds caused by single-edged weapons, characterized by splits at the blunt end of a triangular wound, aiding in weapon identification.

questions.text: Identify the wound from the image of the neck given below.
questions.solution:
1. Suicidal cutthroat wound:
    • Characterized by hesitation cuts(multiple, superficial parallel wounds) that often merge with the main wound.
    • The wound is typically located above the thyroid cartilage and may show a tailing wound on one side (common in suicide cases).
    • Tailing suggests the victim may have altered the weapon's position during the attempt.
  2. Location and Pattern:
    • The presence of multiple cuts on the left side and tailing on the right are key indicators of a suicidal wound

(Why Not Others):

  • Homicidal cutthroat wound:
    • Typically shows a single deep cut below the thyroid cartilage with no hesitation cuts or tailing. The image shows multiple parallel cuts, pointing towards a suicide attempt.
  • Defence wound:
    • Found primarily on the extremities(arms, hands) as the victim tries to ward off an attack. No such wounds are seen on the neck.
  • Chop wound:
    • These are deep, gaping wounds caused by a heavy weapon like an axe or cleaver. The image lacks the depth and severity typical of chop wounds.

Key Takeaway:

Suicidal cutthroat wounds often show multiple hesitation cuts and are usually located above the thyroid cartilage, with possible tailing on one side.

choices.text: Chop wound by angular blow from axe

questions.text: Identify the type of wound and weapon that caused it as shown below in the image of scalp
questions.solution:
1. Lacerated wound by rod:
    • Irregular, ragged, uneven margins, typical of a lacerated wound caused by a hard and blunt object like a rod.
    • The wound lacks sharp, defined edges, indicating blunt force trauma.
  2. Wound Characteristics:
    • The uneven, jagged nature of the wound confirms the use of a blunt object rather than a sharp weapon.

(Why Not Others):

  • Incised wound by knife:
    • Incised wounds have regular, sharp, well-defined margins, not ragged as seen here.
  • Stab wound by knife:
    • Stab wounds are deep, penetrating injuries with clean-cut edges, which is not present in this scalp wound.
  • Chop wound by angular blow from axe:
    • Chop wounds are deep and caused by a moderately sharp object like an axe. Bevelling of margins is often seen with angular blows, which is absent

Key Takeaway:

A lacerated wound shows irregular, ragged margins and is caused by a blunt object like a rod, unlike sharp or penetrating injuries from knives or axes.

questions.text: The injury on the back of torso as shown in the image is most commonly seen in
questions.solution:
Road traffic accident:

  • The injury is characterized as a graze abrasion, also known as gravel rash.
  • Caused by horizontal or tangential friction between the skin and a hard, rough surface, resulting in uneven, longitudinal parallel lines.
  • These lines indicate the direction of force, with the epidermis heaped up at the opposite end.
  • Commonly associated with road traffic accidents, where the body comes into contact with the road surface.

(Why Not Others):

  • Hanging:
    • Produces pressure abrasions, which are different from graze abrasions. The injury mechanism does not involve horizontal friction.
  • Drowning in flowing river:
    • Typically results in water-related injuries, such as bruising or submersion injuries, rather than graze abrasions.
  • Flame burns:
    • Associated with thermal injuries and show burn patterns, not abrasions. They are usually seen in firearm injuries based on the distance from which the weapon is fired.

Key Takeaway:

Injuries characterized as graze abrasions with parallel lines are most commonly seen in road traffic accidents, where friction against a rough surface occurs.

questions.text: Identify the type of bruise from the given image and choose the correct option.
questions.solution:
Tram-line or railway-line bruise:

  • Caused by blows with a rod, stick, or whip, resulting in two parallel linear hemorrhages.
  • The skin between the bruises appears unchanged.
  • Solid stick bruises are confined to the convexity of the body, while a flexible strap creates longer, curved tram-line bruises.

(Why Not Others):

  • Grey Turner's sign:
    • Refers to ecchymosis(bruising) over the flank or side of the abdomen due to extensive retroperitoneal hemorrhage, developing 24-48 hours after injury.
  • Cullen's sign:
    • Characterized by bluish-black discoloration around the periumbilical area due to significant intra-abdominal hemorrhage, often from conditions like ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • Battle's sign:
    • A bruise located behind the ear indicating a basal skull fracture, unrelated to tram-line bruising.

Key Takeaway:

A tram-line or railway line bruise is marked by two parallel hemorrhages caused by a rod or whip, with unchanged skin in between, typical of specific blunt force trauma.

choices.text: Smaller than the diameter of the bullet
Bruising, abrasion and grease collar present
Radiological examination may show lead ring

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT the feature of a Firearm entry wound?
questions.solution:
Why Not Others:

  • Smaller than the diameter of the bullet:
    • Entry wounds are typically smaller than the bullet's diameter, except in contact shots, due to the constricting nature of the tissue.
  • Bruising, abrasion, and grease collar present:
    • These features are commonly associated with entry wounds, indicating soft tissue damage and the presence of gunpowder residue.
  • Radiological examination may show lead ring:
    • A lead ring may be visible in radiological exams, indicating lead residues from the bullet in entry wounds.

Key Takeaway:

Everted edges are a feature of exit wounds, whereas entry wounds exhibit inverted edges, smaller size, and associated bruising and grease collars.

choices.text: Caused on victim's body to ward of the attack by assailant
Occurs when victim tries to seize the weapon
Occurs passively when victim raises arms to ward off attack
Occurs when victim is taken by surprise

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT the characteristics of a defense wound?
questions.solution:
Defense Wound Characteristics:

  • Location: Typically found on the extremities(arms and hands), as these are the areas most often used to protect oneself during an attack.
  • Immediate Response: They result from an immediate and instinctive reaction by the victim to avoid harm from an assailant.
  • Types of Defense Injuries:
    • Active defense injuries occur when the victim actively engages the attacker, such as trying to seize the weapon.
    • Passive defense injuries arise when the victim instinctively raises their arms or flexes their body to shield vital organs from harm.
  • Absence of Defense Wounds: Such wounds may be absent if the victim is unconscious, attacked from behind, or under the influence of alcohol or drugs, inhibiting their ability to react.

(Why Not Others):

  • Caused on victim's body to ward off the attack by assailant:
    • Defense wounds are specifically inflicted when the victim actively tries to protect themselves from an assailant's attack.
  • Occurs when victim tries to seize the weapon:
    • This describes active defense injuries, where the victim attempts to take control of the weapon, leading to defensive wounds.
  • Occurs passively when victim raises arms to ward off attack:
    • This describes passive defense injuries, where the victim instinctively raises their arms to shield vital areas, resulting in wounds on the extremities.

Key Takeaway:

Defense wounds arise from the victim's instinctive actions to protect themselves, while no such wounds occur if the victim is caught by surprise or unable to react.

questions.text:
Choose the correct option regarding rifling in firearms
(i) Imparts gyroscopic stability
(ii) Increases accuracy and range
(iii) Imparts end-to-end tumbling
(iv) Gives greater power of penetration
questions.solution:
1. Rifling Characteristics:
    • The bore of a firearm is scored with shallow spiral grooves (commonly 4, 5, or 6) that run parallel and twist from the breech to the muzzle.
    • The grooves are known as rifling, and the projecting ridges between them are referred to as lands.
  2. Functions of Rifling:
    • Imparts gyroscopic stability: Ensures that the projectile maintains a straight trajectory during flight.
    • Increases accuracy and range: The rifling stabilizes the bullet, allowing for improved precision and extended distance.
    • Prevents end-to-end tumbling: This is incorrect; rifling prevents wobbling but does not cause tumbling.
    • Gives greater power of penetration: The stability from rifling allows the bullet to penetrate targets more effectively.

(Why Not Others):

  • (i), (ii) & (iii) are correct:
    • Incorrect because rifling does not impart end-to-end tumbling; it prevents it.
  • (i), (iii) & (iv) are correct:
    • Incorrect for the same reason as option A; tumbling is not a function of rifling.
  • All are correct:
    • Incorrect as it includes the false statement about tumbling.

Key Takeaway:

Rifling in firearms enhances gyroscopic stability, improves accuracy and range, and increases penetration, while it does not cause tumbling, contrary to the incorrect options.

questions.text: Identify the type of bore from the below image
questions.solution:
1. Type of Bore Identified:
    • Cylinder bore is characterized by having no constriction; the entire barrel maintains a consistent diameter from the breech to the muzzle.
  2. Choking Explained:
    • Choking refers to an interior constriction at the muzzle of a shotgun barrel, designed to control the shot pattern upon firing.
    • Choke Bore: This is where constriction occurs in the last 7-10 cm of the barrel.
  3. Characteristics of Cylinder Bore:
    • Unchoked: It allows for a wide spread of shot, resulting in a larger pattern.
    • Rate of Spread: It has a higher rate of spread compared to choked barrels, leading to less explosive force and reduced range.
    • Measurement of Discharge: The effective range can be estimated by measuring the diameter of the wound made by the outermost individual pellet, divided by three to convert to meters.

(Why Not Others):

  • Improved cylinder:
    • This type has a slight constriction, providing a tighter shot pattern than a cylinder bore.
  • Modified choke:
    • A modified choke provides moderate constriction, resulting in a tighter pattern than improved cylinder but still broader than full choke.
  • Full choke:
    • This type has the most constriction, producing the tightest shot pattern and greater range compared to cylinder bore.

Key Takeaway:

The cylinder bore is unchoked, maintaining a uniform diameter throughout, resulting in a wider shot spread, while other types of chokes provide varying levels of constriction for different shot patterns.

questions.text: The cruciate or stellate laceration is seen in rifled firearm wounds from
questions.solution:
1. Type of Laceration Identified:
    • Cruciate or stellate laceration is characteristic of contact shots, particularly evident when thick bone (like the skull) is directly beneath the skin.
  2. Mechanism of Injury:
    • The blowback phenomenon occurs when gases expand beneath the skin and escape through the entry wound, causing the irregular, ragged edges associated with cruciate lacerations.
  3. Wound Characteristics Based on Shot Range:
    • Contact Shot: Results in stellate lacerations due to gas expansion and tissue disruption.
    • Close Shot (Flame Range): Produces circular wounds with an abrasion collar but lacks the characteristic laceration.
    • Near Shot (Medium Range): Similar to close shots, these wounds are generally circular and do not exhibit stellate lacerations.
    • Distant Shot: Typically results in clean circular wounds with no laceration or gas-related effects.

(Why Not Others):

  • Close shot (flame range):
    • Produces circular wounds with an abrasion collar but lacks the irregularity of cruciate lacerations.
  • Near shot (medium range):
    • Similar to close shots, leading to circular wounds without the specific characteristics of stellate lacerations.
  • Distant shot:
    • Results in clean, circular wounds with no associated lacerations or gas expansion effects.

Key Takeaway:

Cruciate or stellate lacerations are indicative of contact shots, arising from the blowback phenomenon caused by gas expansion, while shots at close, medium, or distant ranges result in more circular wounds with no laceration.

questions.text: The rat-hole appearance of wound of entry in a shotgun is seen at a firing distance of
questions.solution:
A rat-hole appearance of the entry wound of a shotgun can be seen from 30 cm to 1 metres of range.

Shotgun ranges are classified as:

  • Contact and near contact shots.
  • Close Range (up to one metre)
  • Short range (1 to 2 metres)
  • Intermediate Range (2 to 4 metres)
  • Long or Distant range (above 4 metres)

When a shotgun is fired, initially all the pellets move out of the barrel as a single mass up to 2 metres (Single wound of entry), after which the peripheral pellets start dispersing from 2 - 4 metres (Main wound + satellite wounds), then there will be complete dispersion beyond 4 metres (Multiple wounds of entry).

Rat-hole wounds: Between 30 cm to one metre, the rim of the wound is irregular and shows some scalloping, often referred to as a "rat -hole". There may be annular abrasions and bruising or "rat nibbling".

The image given below shows characteristics of shotgun wounds at various ranges.

Key Takeaway:


The rat hole appearance is distinctive of shotgun wounds at a distance of 30cm to 100cm, formed by a single mass entry of shot.

questions.text: The surgical alteration of gunshot wound renders difficulty in the evaluation of Firearm wound. It is also known as
questions.solution:
1. Term Identified:
    • The surgical alteration of gunshot wounds complicating the evaluation of the wound is known as the Kennedy phenomenon.
  2. Impact on Wound Evaluation:
    • Surgical changes, such as suturing, make it challenging to determine whether the wound is an entrance or exit wound due to altered characteristics.
  3. Related Phenomena Explained:
    • Back Spatter: Occurs in contact shots when the muzzle blast creates negative pressure, pulling blood, hair, and tissue fragments back into the barrel.
    • Blowback Phenomenon: Associated with cruciate lacerations when gases expand beneath the skin and exit through the entry wound, especially over a thick bone like the skull.

(Why Not Others):

  • Back spatter:
    • Refers specifically to the recirculation of blood and tissue into the firearm during a contact shot, not related to surgical alterations.
  • Blowback phenomenon:
    • Concerns the expansion of gases causing lacerations and does not address the challenges in evaluating gunshot wounds post-surgery.
  • Billiard ball ricochet effect:
    • Describes the trajectory of pellets bouncing off surfaces but is not related to surgical alterations of wounds.

Key Takeaway:

The Kennedy phenomenon refers to the complications in evaluating gunshot wounds due to surgical alterations, impacting the ability to distinguish between entrance and exit wounds. Other terms describe different ballistic effects or mechanisms related to gunshot injuries.

choices.text: Only inner table is fractured and not the outer table
Can be caused by forcible compression with obstetric forceps

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT the characteristic of pond fracture?
questions.solution:
1. Definition of Pond Fracture:
    • Pond fracture(also known as indented fracture or ping-pong fracture) is characterized by a smooth concave depression in the skull resulting from in-buckling.
  2. Characteristics of Pond Fracture:
    • Occurs in Infants and Children: Common in children, particularly before 4 years of age due to the flexibility of their skulls.
    • In-Buckling of Skull: The fracture results from the skull's in-buckling, creating a characteristic depression.
    • Meninges and Brain Integrity: Typically, the inner table of the skull remains intact, and there is no damage to the meninges or brain.
    • Caused by External Forces: Can be caused by forcible compression(e.g., using obstetric forceps) or impact with protruding objects during delivery.

(Why Not Others):

  • Occurs in infants and children:
    • This is a characteristic of pond fractures, as they are commonly seen in this age group.
  • Results from in-buckling of skull:
    • This describes the mechanism of a pond fracture, confirming it as a key feature.
  • Can be caused by forcible compression with obstetric forceps:
    • This is true, as such compression can lead to the development of a pond fracture.

Key Takeaway:

Pond fractures are characterized by in-buckling of the skull in infants and children, preserving the integrity of the inner table and meninges, while the statement that only the inner table is fractured is incorrect.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about concussion?
(i) Retrograde amnesia which is unrelieved by time
(ii) Behaviour is uncooperative, abusive, talkative
(iii) Light reflex is sluggish
(iv) Face is pale and cold
questions.solution:
1. Definition of Concussion:
    • Concussion is a traumatic brain injury that affects brain function, often resulting from a blow to the head.
  2. Correct Statements About Concussion:
    • (i) Retrograde Amnesia: Concussion often leads to retrograde amnesia, which is not relieved by time-meaning past memories may remain inaccessible.
    • (iv) Physical Symptoms: Patients may present with a pale and cold face, indicative of the body's response to the injury.
  3. Incorrect Statements:
    • (ii) Behaviour: Typically, individuals with concussion tend to be quiet and retracted, rather than uncooperative or talkative.
    • (iii) Light Reflex: Reflexes may be sluggish but can also be brisk.

(Why Not Others):

  • (i), (ii) & (iii) are correct:
    • Incorrect as (ii) is not a typical behavior for concussion patients.
  • (ii), (iii) & (iv) are correct:
    • Incorrect due to (ii) and (iii) being mischaracterizations of concussion symptoms.
  • (ii) & (iv) are correct:
    • Incorrect since (ii) is not representative of typical concussion behavior.

Key Takeaway:

In concussion, retrograde amnesia is common and often not relieved by time, with patients typically exhibiting a pale and cold appearance. Other described behaviors and reflex responses do not accurately represent concussion characteristics.

choices.text: Coup injury on right side and contrecoup on left side
Contrecoup injury of left side and coup on right side

questions.text: The findings on CT scan of a person having struck by baseball bat on right temporal region showed hyperdense lesions on both right and left side. Choose the correct statement about the type of injury.
questions.solution:
1. Injury Type:
    • The CT scan findings show hyperdense lesions on the left side after impact on the right temporal region, indicating a coup injury on the impacted side (right) and a contrecoup injury on the opposite side (left).
  2. Definitions:
    • Coup Injury:
      • Occurs beneath the impact site; caused by direct force.
    • Contrecoup Injury:
      • Lesion is located opposite the impact site; results from vacuum and suction forces.
  1. CT Scan Characteristics:
    • Infarction typically appears as hypodense regions; hyperdense lesions suggest bleeding or contusions rather than infarction.

(Why Not Others):

  • Contrecoup injury of left side and coup on right side:
    • Incorrect; the coup injury is on the side of impact (right).
  • Infarction on left side:
    • Incorrect; infarction appears hypodense, not hyperdense.
  • Infarction on right side:
    • Incorrect; similar reasoning as above regarding hyperdensity.

Key Takeaway:

The findings indicate a coup injury on the right side where the baseball bat struck, and a contrecoup injury on the left, consistent with the mechanisms of brain injury following blunt trauma.

choices.text: Most common cause is Trauma (associated with skull fracture) & source of bleeding is middle meningeal artery (arterial)
Most common cause is Trauma & source of bleeding is Bridging veins (venous)
Most common cause is Aneurysm rupture & source of bleeding is Berry aneurysm (arterial)
Most common cause is Hypertension & source of bleeding is Lenticulostriate artery (arterial)

questions.text: Identify the type of intracranial hemorrhage and choose the correct option
questions.solution:
1. Type of Hemorrhage:
    • The hemorrhage identified is Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH).
  2. Causes and Source:
    • Most Common Cause: Trauma associated with skull fracture.
    • Source of Bleeding: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery(arterial source).
  3. Characteristics of EDH:
    • Occurs on the side of impact and is limited by dural attachments at suture lines.
    • Typically presents with a lens-shaped mass on imaging.

(Why Not Others):

  • Most common cause is Trauma & source of bleeding is Bridging veins (venous):
    • Incorrect; this describes Subdural Hemorrhage (SDH), not EDH.
  • Most common cause is Aneurysm rupture & source of bleeding is Berry aneurysm (arterial):
    • Incorrect; this pertains to Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH), not EDH.
  • Most common cause is Hypertension & source of bleeding is Lenticulostriate artery (arterial):
    • Incorrect; this relates to Intracerebral Hemorrhage (ICH).

Key Takeaway:

Extradural Hemorrhage is primarily caused by trauma, specifically involving the rupture of the middle meningeal artery, leading to significant clinical consequences if not addressed promptly.

questions.text: A person was assaulted by fist and blows during a domestic quarrel. The police brought 3 persons for examination. The findings on the X-ray are as below. Which is the type of fracture.
questions.solution:
1. Type of Fracture:
    • The identified fracture is a Boxer's fracture.
  2. Characteristics:
    • Occurs at the neck of the fifth metacarpal bone.
    • Commonly results from striking a firm surface with a closed fist during a fight.
  3. Differential Diagnosis:
    • Fissure Fracture: Linear cracks in the bone without depression.
    • Ping Pong Fracture (Pond Fracture): In-buckling of the skull without any fracture line, typically seen in infants.
    • Hinge Fracture (Motorcyclist's Fracture): A fracture at the base of the skull that creates a hinge effect.

(Why Not Others):

  • A. Ping pong fracture:
    • Incorrect; relates to skull fractures in infants without damage to the brain.
  • B. Fissure fracture:
    • Incorrect; involves linear cracks without displacement, not associated with blunt force.
  • C. Hinge fracture:
    • Incorrect; refers to skull fractures causing a "hinge" effect, typically not caused by fist strikes.

Key Takeaway:

Boxer's fracture is a common injury from direct trauma to the hand, particularly in altercations, emphasizing the importance of understanding the mechanisms of injury in forensic examinations.

choices.text: It is a period of consciousness between two episodes of unconsciousness.
It can occur in patients with Extradural haemorrhage.
The initial brain injury is concussion followed by bleeding from sagittal sinus.
The patient appears normal during the lucid interval.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding lucid interval?
questions.solution:
1. Definition:
    • Lucid Interval: A period of consciousness between two episodes of unconsciousness.
  2. Relevance:
    • Commonly observed in cases of Extradural Hemorrhage (EDH).
  3. Characteristics:
    • The patient appears normal and conscious during the lucid interval.
    • The initial injury leading to the lucid interval is typically a concussion, followed by a middle meningeal artery bleed, not a bleed from the sagittal sinus.

(Why Not Others):

  • A. It is a period of consciousness between two episodes of unconsciousness:
    • True; this is the definition of a lucid interval.
  • B. It can occur in patients with Extradural hemorrhage:
    • True; lucid intervals are characteristic of EDH.
  • D. The patient appears normal during the lucid interval:
    • True; patients typically appear normal and conscious during this period.

Key Takeaway:

A lucid interval is significant in assessing Extradural Hemorrhage, as it indicates a temporary stabilization before subsequent deterioration, usually due to a middle meningeal bleed.

questions.text:
Which of the following sentences is FALSE regarding flame burns?
a. Heat fracture never cross suture line
b. Heat hematoma has honeycomb appearance
c. Absence of CO in blood rules out death due to flame burn
d. Epidermal burns are very painful
questions.solution:
1. Flame Burns:
    • Associated with exposure to intense heat.
    • Various injuries and characteristics can arise from flame burns.
  2. Key Characteristics:
    • Epidermal Burns:
      • Cause erythema, swelling, and blisters.
      • Very painful; healing occurs without scarring.
    • Heat Hematoma:
      • Appears similar to extradural hemorrhage.
      • Exhibits a honeycomb appearance on cut section due to steam bubbles.
  3. False Statements:
    • (a): Heat fractures never cross suture lines: False; heat fractures can cross suture lines.
    • (c): Absence of CO in blood rules out death due to flame burn: False; Absence of CO can occur for various reasons and does not definitively rule out flame burns.

(Why Not Others):

  • (b): Heat hematoma has honeycomb appearance:
    • True; accurately describes the appearance due to steam bubbles.
  • (d): Epidermal burns are very painful:
    • True; these burns are known for being painful.

Key Takeaway:

Understanding the characteristics and implications of flame burns is crucial, particularly regarding heat fractures and the presence or absence of CO in assessing causes of death in burn cases.

questions.text: The pattern shown in the image is seen in___
questions.solution:
Filigree Burns:

  • Its also known as arborescent marks or Lichtenberg flower marks or feathering or ferning or keraunographic burn.
  • It is a finding seen in about 20-33% of cases of lightning.
  • Its superficial, tortuous, thin, irregular, reddish marks on the skin.
  • Appears like branches of a tree (fern like pattern).
  • Most common site → Shoulder, front of chest, flanks
  • It's not a true burn
  • Its due to the lysis of RBCs along the path of electric current
  • Pink to brownish in color
  • Disappears in about 1-2 daysThe fern-like pattern of erythema in the skin indicates the path taken by the electrical discharge. It usually occurs over the shoulder or the flanks within an hour of the injury and disappears in a day or two. It occurs due to the rupture of small vessels and is seen in a fern-like pattern or the branching of a tree.

(Why Not Others):

  • (a): Fire in road traffic accidents:
    • Does not produce the distinct filigree pattern associated with lightning.
  • (c): Scalds:
    • Result from hot liquids and present a different burn pattern, typically blistering.
  • (d): Chemical burns:
    • Cause tissue damage through chemical reactions, not characterized by arborescent markings.

Key Takeaway:

Recognizing the unique patterns of burns, such as filigree burns from lightning, is crucial for accurate diagnosis and understanding the mechanisms of injury.

questions.text: Marshall's triad in blast injury includes all Except
questions.solution:
1. Marshall's Triad in Blast Injury:
    • Consists of:
      • Bruises
      • Abrasions
      • Punctate lacerations with tattooing
  2. Characteristics:
    • Bruises: Indicate blunt force trauma.
    • Abrasions: Surface injuries from scraping.
    • Punctate Lacerations: Small, pointed wounds with accompanying tattooing from explosive materials.
  3. Exclusion:
    • Burns: Not included in Marshall's triad; related to flash burns or singed hair from explosive devices.

(Why Not Others):

  • (a): Bruise: A key component of Marshall's triad.
  • (b): Abrasions: Another essential component of Marshall's triad.
  • (c): Punctate lacerations with tattooing: Crucial for indicating injuries from explosions.

Key Takeaway:

Marshall's triad helps identify injuries from blast events, highlighting specific wound patterns while excluding burn injuries.

questions.text: Which is the most common organ affected by primary blast injury?
questions.solution:
1. Primary Blast Injury:
    • Characterized by internal injuries without external signs.
    • Often underrecognized and underestimated in severity.
  2. Most Commonly Affected Organ:
    • Ear drum: Most frequently injured due to overpressure from blasts.
    • Lungs: Also affected but less commonly than ear drum.
    • Hollow Organs of the GIT: May be injured but typically present symptoms later.

(Why Not Others):

  • (b): Lungs: Commonly affected but secondary to ear drum injuries in primary blast scenarios.
  • (c): Liver: Not commonly affected by primary blast injury; more relevant in other contexts.
  • (d): Stomach: Injuries may occur but are less immediate compared to ear drum injuries.

Key Takeaway:

In primary blast injuries, ears are the most commonly affected organ, highlighting the impact of overpressure during explosions.

choices.text: Soot particles in upper respiratory tract
Red and inflamed base of vesicles

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT the sign of antemortem burns?
questions.solution:
1. Signs of Antemortem Burns:
    • Line of Redness: Present, indicating inflammation.
    • Soot Particles: Found in the upper respiratory tract.
    • Vesicles: Typically contain serous fluid rich in albumin and chloride, not air.
    • Base of Vesicles: Red and inflamed with an erythematous halo.
  2. Postmortem Burns:
    • Vesicles: May contain air; if fluid is present, it's thin and clear.
    • Base of Vesicles: Dull, dry, and pale without inflammation.

(Why Not Others):

  • (a): Line of redness: A clear sign of inflammation in antemortem burns.
  • (b): Soot particles: Indicative of inhalation injury from a fire, typical of antemortem burns.
  • (d): Red and inflamed base: This reflects ongoing inflammation in antemortem burns.

Key Takeaway:

An air-filled vesicle indicates postmortem changes, not antemortem burns, where vesicles typically contain serous fluid.

choices.text: Calculation of total body surface area affected by burns
Calculation of rate of fluid infusion
Determine the nature of burn (antemortem or postmortem)
Determine the progression of rigor mortis

questions.text: The Wallace rule of nine is used for____
questions.solution:
• Wallace Rule of Nines: A method to estimate total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns in adults.
    • Breakdown:
      • Head and Neck: 9%
      • Each Upper Limb: 9%
      • Front and Back of Each Lower Limb: 18% (9% each)
      • Front and Back of Chest: 18% (9% each)
      • Front and Back of Abdomen: 18% (9% each)

(Why Not Others):

  • (b): Calculation of fluid infusion is typically based on other formulas (like Parkland formula).
  • (c): Determining the nature of burn is not the purpose of this rule.
  • (d): Progression of rigor mortis is assessed through different criteria, not the Wallace Rule.

Key Takeaway:

The Wallace Rule of Nines is specifically designed for calculating the total body surface area affected by burns in adults, aiding in treatment decisions.

choices.text: Primary shock due to pain from burns
Septicemia due to burn wound infections.

questions.text: A patient was admitted to hospital after suffering deep burns from an accident in a factory. The appearance of limbs is as shown in the image below. Similar type of condition was present all over the body. The blood profile showed a raised total leucocyte count. The patient died after 4 days. What is the cause of death?
questions.solution:
• Cause of Death in Burns: Septicemia due to burn wound infections is a major cause of death occurring days after the initial injury.
    • Infection: Common pathogens include Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Timeline:
    • 4-5 Days Post-Burn: High risk of sepsis.
    • Primary Shock: Usually immediate and less than 24 hours post-injury.
    • Hypovolemic Shock: Occurs within 24-48 hours due to fluid loss.

(Why Not Others):

  • (a): Primary shock due to pain is an immediate concern, not the cause of death after several days.
  • (c): Hypovolemic shock occurs sooner and is related to fluid loss, not a primary cause of death at this stage.
  • (d): Smoke inhalation leading to laryngospasm is an immediate cause and not applicable after four days.

Key Takeaway:

In severe burns, the risk of septicemia from infections significantly increases and can lead to death several days post-injury.
